Express steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE,
In connection with the Oriental Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.

PALESTINE-SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.-The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzalah leave Alexandria alter- nately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascous), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Meraina calling fortnightly at Larnsca (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.-The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednes- days at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim and connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.-Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (fir Suez) Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massovah, Hoderdah and Aden For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez or to THOS. TUESDAY, AUGUST 13, 1907

div.head: morocco's trouble.
div.p: Events in Morocco are moving much more swiftly than was anticipated. For, even before the small French expeditionary force, now on its way from Oran to Casa Blanca, has had time to pass from the Mediterranean into the Atlantic, the French warships already on the spot have bombarded the Moorish port. The bombardment was not an affair of blank cartridge. It was carried through in serious earnest, and the Moors are said to have lost heavily in killed and wounded. The engagement, if such a term can be applied to it, was precipitated by the Moors themselves, and, according to one version, was due to the treachery which is engrained in their national character. The French Consulate had asked the commander of the Galilee for a guard of marines, and it was arranged with the Bashaw of Casa Blanca that the guard should be landed. But the marines had no sooner set foot on shore than they were fired upon by the Bashaw's own Moorish troops and by the tribesmen who had come into the town to make common cause with them. An officer and six sailors were wounded, but the rest drove the Moors before them at the point of the bayonet and made their way to the Consulate. Then the bombard- ment began, and the two French crusiers, "DuChayla" and "Galilee", poured shells into the town batteries till they were reduced to ruins, and destroyed the surrounding quarter belong- ing to the hostile tribesmen. The Moors, of course, were quite unable to make any effective reply, and their commander speedily requested a cessation of the bombardment and the pardon of the French admiral, who peremtorily told him to surrender to the French Consul. Only sheer perversity, says the "Daily Telegraph" can suggest any sympathy for the ruffianly Moors who have brought this well-deserved punishment upon their own heads, and the twelve Europeans who were butchered and barbarously mutilated the other day have thus, in a sense, been promptly avenged. But the

bombardment does not close the chapter. Rather, it begins a new one, of which the sequel is beyond all guessing. "Only God knoweth" is a favourite Moorish proverb, and it is peculiarly applicable to the present case. But Monday's events have cleared the way for the arrival of General Drude and the little army of three thousand and have given the Moors a foretaste of what they may ex- pect if they indulge in further acts of hostility. It is important to note that the Spanish gun boat landed a party of firty marines for the protection of the Spanish Consulate, while a force of five hundred Spanish troops is under orders to-operate with General Drude. No one can over-estimate the value at this juncture of a thoroughly good understanding between the French and Spanish Governments, who were designated by the Convention of Algeciras to act as the mandatories of Europe, insomuch as they were authorised to organise a police force for Morocco. For the tranquility of the diplo- matic world it is essential that this co-opera- tion shall continue, and the Spanish Govern- ment, while naturally anxious not to become involved in Morocco more deeply than the honour of Spain requires, is to be congratulated on ignoring the outcry raised against its intervention by a strong section of the Opposi- tion, which has throughout disliked the role assigned to and accepted by Spain.

Unquestionably, the situation is serious though the steps taken by France are re- proachable, and her intentions have been announced to and have received the approval of all the Great Powers. Such is the perfect confidence reposed in the Government of the Republic by Great Britain that is now declared that no British warship will be sent to Casa Blanca, inasmuch as the measures to be taken by the French are considered entirely adequate for the protection of British interests. We hope that other Powers will show a like con- fidence, if only to help to convince the Moors that they cannot expect to derive any advant- age from international jealousies. Unfor- tunately, the Sultan of Morocco, with whom France and Spain will have to deal, exercises but a very shadowy and slender authority over his own officials, such as the Bashaw of Casa Blanca, and still less over the Kabyle tribes aneu, who are practically responsible for the recent outrages. The Maghzen have hastened to express to the French Minister at Few their "profound regret" for the outbreak, just as they regretted the murder of Dr. Mauchamps near the Algerian border at Marrakesh. Both regrets are useless when they are not backed by any prood of their sincerity. No once behaves in the desire of the Maghzen to put a stop to fanatical murders, and if they had the desire it is more than doubtful if they have the power. For these abominable outrages are ebullitions of strong national feeling against the introduction of an unwelcome civilisation, and against the appearance of the Cross in the hand of the Crescent. The most powerful factor in Morocco is not the Sultan, not the Pretender, nor Raisuli, but Ma El Ainin, the holy man of the desert at the back of Capy Juby. He is the Maharaj of the land, and a "holy war: in Morocco is not a contingency that any Power could face with equanimity. Bombardments always have sequels. No Englishman--and no Frenchman for that matter--will forget what a surprising chain of events has followed the shelling of Alexandria. When a European nation has landed an expeditionary force in a town after a bombardment which has shattered the half-savage authority, it finds it no easy matter to withdraw, for it cannot face the respectibi- lity of leaving anarchy rampant. With a strong central Moorish Government, on which de- pendence could be placed, the positions of affairs would be much simpler. Satisfaction could be demanded, and when it had been given the avenging force could retire. In this case withdrawal will be hazardous, inasmuch as other outrages are almost certain to follow --they are already threatened at Rabat and elsewhere--whether there is holy war or not. France and Spain will, of course, act with resolution, and will not shrink because the future is uncertain and the commitment may be heavy. But those who know the story of the conquest and occupation of Algeria will not uner-estimate the risks and strain of a gue- rilla war in a difficult and practically unknown country, and against wild races of the martial quality of the Moors. They will appreciate, moreover, the anxieties which would weigh upon Ministers at Paris and Madrid, even if-- which is, perhaps, rather too much to hope-- none but friendly and sympathetic eyes were watching the fulfilment of the task.

Le vent a tourne. Des l'ouverture de la corbeille kes vendeurs, hier encour introu- vables, etaient a la recherche des acheteaurs qui avaient a leur tour disparu. Il parait qu'il a'agit de realisations de progit. Ce sont donc les memes qui ont-schete ces jours derniers a des prix avantageux qui veulent aujourd'hui vendre pour realiser les benefices acquis. Dans ce cas, l'explication a la volte-face de ce matin est toute trouvee. Les acheteurs de naguere se sont tout simplement transformes en vendeurs: maid le revirement a ete trop rapide et trop una- nime a la fois pour permettre aux interesses de faire leur operationl.C'edt pourquoinotre marche a debutefaible et en baisse et vette allure s'est maintenue jusqu'a la fin de la seance. I; y a eu quelques transactions clairsemees en Agricole, National. Bank et quelques autres valeurs, maid les operations n'ont eu d'importance qu'en Estates et en United.

Les valeurs dirigeantes sont toutes en reaction : l'Agricole flechit de 8 3/16 ache- teurs a 8 3/18 vendeurs, la National Bank de 20 5/8 a 20 1/2, la Delta Light de 9 13/16 a 9 3/4, la Daira de 13 a 12 15/16 et l'Obligation Credit Foncier de 304 l'ancien- ne et 260 la nouvelle a 303 1/2 et 259 respectivement.

En baisse egalement les Dividendes Tram- ways de 300 a 297, la Behera de 20 5/8 a 20 1/2, les Lots Turcs de 165 a 164, l'ac- tion Khedivial Mail de 4 a 3 7/8, la Land Bank de 7 1/4 a 7 le Com- ptoir de 3 1/8 a 3.

Quelques titres, au c , avant ete l'objet d'une demande su ont beneficio d'une avance. C'est ainsi que lamleh pro- gresse de 4 11/16 a 5, les Eaux du Caire de 114 les actions de capital et 190 les actions de jouissance aux cours respectifs de 114 et 192, les. Biere du Caire de 87 a 89 les Privilegiees et de 35 a 38 les Dividendes, la Building Lands de 2 3/8 a 2 1/2, le Credit Franco-Egyptien de 4 3/16 a 4 1/4 et l'ac- tion Allotment de 2 1/2 a 2 13/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Salt and Soda revient de 19 a 18/6, la Delta Land de 2 1/8 a 2 1/16, les Sucreries de 30 a 25, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 21/6 a 21/3, les Estates de 7/8 a 3/4 scheteurs, la Levico de 7/16 a 15/32, tandia que les fondateurs Allotment et United s'avancent, la premiere de 75 a 80 P.T. et la seconde de 2 1/2 a 2 9/16.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de chan- gements a signaler.

Les marches europeans temoignent en gene- ral d'une reaction repondant a la hausse du taux d'escompte et a la baisse du Consolide Anglais et de la Rente Francaise. Il n'y a que les valeurs egyptiennes qui dont preuve d'un soutien aussi exceptionnel que l'avait ete leur recente depression. Il s'agit probablement du retablissement d'un equilibre qui avait ete rompu par l'exageration de la baisse des valeurs egyptiennes.
Cireulaire H. De. Vries et Boutiny
NOTES BT CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Lundi 12 Aout
Le taux de l'escompte libre est reste, samedi dernier a Londres, a 4 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a perdu pour les deux derniers jours de la se- maine 3/4 de livre a 81 1/8. L'Unifiee est restee inchangee a 101 1/2. La National Bank a gagne 1/4 a 20 1/4. L'Agricole s'est maintenue ferme a 8 1/8, ainsi que la Daira a 12 3/4 et la Delta Light a 10.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a reac- tionne de 1 franc a 687. La Banque d'Athenes a ete soutenue a 112 et les Lots Turcs ont fait 167 sans changement.

Bien que la reprise ait commence, il y a deja passablement de temps, le marche ne montre pas encoure d'essoudlement : bien au contraire, la hausse s'est affirmee plus franche durant la seance de ce jour, passant d'une valeur a une autre. Il est actuellement tangible que les placements deviennent de jour en jour plus nombreux, et si l'on ajoute que les vendeurs se terrent avec l'esperance de beneficier plus largement en ayant un peu de patience, il ap- parait comme tres comprehensible que la cote ait present aujourd'hui en cloture une hausse generale. Il y a di reste peu a crainde, car les transactions se faissant au comptant et toutes les valeurs etant encore a des prix tres bas, une reaction, toujours possible, ne pourrait pas etre bien serieuse.
Quoiqu'il en soit, la seanse a ete excellente, et elle aurait ete beaucoup plus animee si les vendeurs n'avaient pas ete introuvables pour de nombreux titres.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na- tional Bank hausse a 20 5/8-11-16 en avance de 3/8 sur son dernier cours. L'Agricole fait de meme a 8 1/8-3/16. La Cassa di Sconto remonte a 42 et la Banque d'Athenes a 114.

Les Jouissance Eaux du Caire en bonne de- mande font 192. La Daira Sanieh s'inscrit en legere avance a 12 13/16. Les Obligations au- ciennes du Credit Foncier se relevent a 305 et les nouvelles a 260-261. L'Allotment a avance a 2 9/16 et sa part a P.T. 70. Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux, des plus actives, bondissent a 2 5/8 et leur part a P.T. 44. Les Heliopolis sont recherchees a 247.
Dans les Industrielles, la Brasserie de Pyra- mides remonte a 90 et sa fondateur a 39. La Salt and Soda est en reprise a 18.
Dans le groupe des Hotels, les Baehler sont les favoris et gagnent 9/16 a 6. Les Upper Egypt es consolident a 2 13/16 et les fonda- teurs National Hotels s'inscrivent demandes a P.T. 32.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land clu- ture en mourelle avance a 2 1/8-8/16. Les Es- tates montent a 07/8, leur part molliet a 3 7/8-4. Les Constructions sont indecises a 0 1 2-9 16. Les Abdy en bonne tendance finissent a0 11 16- 3/4. Les Oasis (Western Egypt) a 0 1 2-9 16 et les fondateurs United Land a 3 3 8.
Nous detachons de notre correspondance d'Alexandrie, les passages suivants :

"La semaine ecoulee a presente, malgre une activite peu intense au debut, une amelioration considerable sur la precedente. Cette meilleure tenue du marche provient en grande partie des cours soutenus que Londres nous envoie egu- liarement depui quelqu temps.

"Cette persistance de nos valeurs daos leur fermete a Londres a fini par influencer les esprits, et, comme une eclairvie se produit in dubitablement sur notre place, les haussiers n'ont pas eu de peine a faire remonter de plu- sieurs fractions l'ensemble de la cote. Le ven deurs deviennent, du reste, beucoup plus cir conspects. Voyant le vent souffler a la hausse, ils s'abstiennent avec l'espoir de liquider a des cours muilleurs, et ils n'ont pas tort.

"Un considere isi que ia recoire cotonniere se presentant sous des apparences tre favors- bles, il en adviendra un agjuvant enorme pour le pays et meme la disparition d'une crise que l'on avait un peu entretenue comme un convalescent sa maladie.

"Au sujet du marche a terme dont on vient de decider le retablissement, les avis sont partages, mais l'immense majorite s'y montre favorable, motivant son appreciation sur le fait que sans marche a terme une Bourse n'a que peu de raison d'etre, les transactions au comptant pouvant se faire partout sans grand inconvenient."

D'un etat comparatif des recettes des Egyptian Markets, il resulte que les benefices pour l'exercise 1906-1907 s'elevent actuelle- ment a 25,890 contre 21,800 pour la meme periode de l'exercice precedent.
Les recettes en 1904 s'eleverent a 26, 602, en 1905 a 26, 537 et en 1906 a 36, 773.
La diminuation en 1905 s'explique par suite de la fermeture des marches vu l'epidemie de peste animale qui sevissait alors.
Les recettes de l'Egyptian Delta Light Railways pour la semaine au 2 Aout 1907 s'elevent a L.E. 4,644 contre L.E. 4,029 pour la semaine correspondante en 1906, soit en augmentation de L.E. 615.
Les recettes totales depius de 1 Avril 1907 s'elevent a L.E. 82,609 contre L.E. 68,975 pour la periode correspondante en 1906, soit une plus-value de L.E. 13,634.

div.head: TELEGRAMS.
THE CASABLANCA AFFAIR. GENERAL DISTURBANCE OF TRIBESMEN. SITUATION AT MAZAGAN.
div.p: General satisfaction is expressed throughout the country at the distinguished gallantry of the troops and marines at Casablanca and the effective continuous shell-fire which has re- stored confidence in the guns, but there is some anxiety as to the duration and extent of the warfare.
The events in Casablanca have stirred up the tribesmen in all directions, endangering the position of Europeans on the coast and inland.

The Government does not intend to send reinforcements to Morocco, the troops under General Drude being considered sufficient. The movements of transports from Toulon to Oran is merely precautionary.(Reuter)

The population is preventing Europeans from embarking because their presence shelters the town from bombardment. arrived at the gates of the town and demanding money. Thecommander on the cruiser "Admiral Aube" has the Governor that he will land men and bombard the outskirts of the town.(Reuter)

Some fresh attacks were made at Casablanca on Saturday night, during the course of which one of the French soldiers was killed and ten wounded. The Moors were repulsed with great losses. The number of troops are considered sufficient and a police force is being organised among them. Every precaution is taken to guard against eventualities. Spain is sending reinforcements. The neighbouring tribes of Magazan are de- manding money and the treatening to attack in case of refusal. Admiral Aube is ready to land troops and bombard.(Havas)

div.head: THE LIBERAL GOVERNMENT.
EARL OF SEFTON RESIGNS.
div.p: The Earl of Sefton has resigned the post of Master of the Horse owing to disagreement with the extreme measures of the Government.(Reuter)

div.head: THE BELFAST RIOTS
MORE TROOPS REQUIRED
div.p: 25 soldiers, including two officers, were wounded in yesterday's rioting. Many arrests have been made. 40 rioters and two women have been treated in hospital. The authorities have requested more troops to be send. (Reuter)

A riot occurred yesterday evening arising out of an attempt to rescue prisoners: the poloice made repeated baton charges and the military were ultimately called out : the infantry used bayonets, and the cavalry were compelled to charge : the rioters threw broken bottles : many were wounded on both sides : 500 policemen and 1,500 soldiers were on the scene.(Reuter)
TURKEY AND PERSIA.

It was stated in Parliament on Saturday that Prince Ferman Firms had arranged for 10,000 men to be ready to proceed to the tier shortly. The Prince left here on Sunday. It is reported that half the Turk- ish force is marching towards Sauilalagh. (Reuter)

div.head: EGYPT AND INDIA.
COMPARISON AND CONTRAST.
By Sir Edward Candy.
(Continued from August 10)
div.p: Discussing Pan-Islamism, with which the Egyptian national movement is deeply tinged, Lord Cromer tells us that Pan-Islamism is generally held to mean a combination of all the Muslums throughout the world to defy and to resist the Christian powers. It is, more- over, a convenient phrase for conveying a num- ber of other ideas, more or less connected with its primary signification. In the first place it means, in Egypt, more or less subserviency to the Sultan ; but the later version of the programme of the leasers of the national move- ment is that they have no wish to draw closer the bonds between Turkey and Egypt, and their only desire is to maintain the suzerainty of the Sultan. In the second place Pan-Islamism almost necessarily denotes a recrudescence of racial and religious animosity ; and in the third place an attempt to regenerate Islam on Islamic lines ; in other words, to revivify and stereotype in the twentieth century the prin- ciples laid down more than a thousand years ago for the guidance of a primative society. On the other hand, there are, as Lord Cromer points out, a small but increasing number of Egyptians, of whom comparatively little is heard, but who deserve the title of Nationalist quite as much as their competitors of a different school of though and action, men who hold opinions very analogous to those advocated by the late Seyyid Ahmed, who founded the Aligarh College in India. Their fundamental idea [Lord Cromer says] is to reform various Moslem institutions with- out shaking the main pillars on which the faith of Islam rests. They are truly Nationa- list, in the sense of wishing to advance the interests of their countrymen and co-religion- ists, but they are not tainted with Pan-Islam- ism. Their programme involves not opposition to, but co-operation with, Europeans in the introduction of Western civilisation into the country. The main hope of Egyptian Nationa- lism, in the only true and practicable sense of the word, lies with those who belong to this party. Is there any chance of Pan-Islamism--such as Lord Cromer describes, or in any other shape--being developed in India. According to the last census the total number of Mu- hammadans is 62 1/2 millions or 212 per mile per population of the Indian Empire. No doubt, as Lord Cromer says of Egypt, there are some Moslems who would be willing, were such a course is possible, to seperate the political from the religious and even possibly from the racial issues. But he adds : If such are their wishes and intentions, I entertain very little doubt that they will find them impossible of execution. Unless they can convince the Moslem masses of their militant Islamism, they will fail to arrest their attention or to attract their sympa- thy. Appeals, either overt or covert, to social and religious passions, are thus a necessity of their existence in order to ensure the furtherance of their political programme. This is equally true in India. I need not do more than allude to recent events which show that the idea of a Pan-Islamic movement in India, embracing the whole country, and bring- ing back what I may term the "Moghal Raj" is inconceivable, at least unless the British Government retires altogether, and leaves the continent to anarchy and confusion, the final result of which might possibly by the establish- ment of a Muhammadan kingdom. Referring to the position of the national movement, independently of any real or im- aginary connection it may have with Pan- Islamism, Lord Cromer explains how more than doubtful is the extent to which the so-called National party represents the real wishes and aspirations of the mass of people. Nothing could be more ungenerous than to withhold sympathy from the legitimate aspirations of the educated youth for a greater share in the government of their country ; but nothing could be more unwise than to abstain from pointing out the limits which must be assigned to those aspirations. Further, Lord Cromer very properly insists that European agency is required in Egypt in the first place to supply the technical knowledge which, until very recently, the Egyptians have had no opportunity of acquiring ; in the second place to remedy those defects in the Egyptian character which have been developed by a long course of misgovernment.

Under the first book of the sanguine view, but he does not fail to remind us that the process of substituting indigenous for European agency must be slow. "Any attempt to hurry can only lead to disappoint- ment and eventually in all probability to a reaction which will be to the detriment of Egyptian interest. Under the second head he shows that the substitution of Egyptian for European agency must necessarily take even more time in these cases than in those where the transfer depends on the acquisition of technical knowledge by the Egyptians. And he adds that amongst the defects which, for purposes of administration, appear most of all to require rectification, are the fear of assuming individual responsibility the absence of adequate capacity to exercise with firmness, intelligence, and consideration for others, such functions as are usually vest- ed in responsible agents, and the tendency, so common amongst the Egyptians of run- ning to extremes both in thought and action.

Regarding the wider and more strictly political portion of the National programme what is proposed is, first, the creation of a Ministry reponsible to the chamber, and depen- dent for its existence on the maintenance of the majority ; and secondly complete con- trol over the finances of the country, such as that exercised by the elected Chambers in the United Kingdom and in other European countries. The adoption of the first of these proposals would, in Lord Cromer's opinion, produce a state of things which may, without exaggeration, be termed chaotic. Intrigue of all sorts would be rife. The system of bribery and corruption, which was at one time so pre- valent in the country, and which is even now only dying a lingering death, would receive a freach impuse. It is more than probable that under the specious title of free institutions the wose evils of personal government would reappear. The adoption of the second proposal --that of handing over complete financial con- trol to the Chamber--would almost inevitably lead to National bankruptcy. Is there then no hope for Egyptian Nationalism? Lord Cromer's counter programme is the creation of a local International Council, which would create a community of interests among the heteroge- neous population which inhabits the valley of the Nile, and would thus be the first step towards the formation of an Egyptian National spirit in the only sense in which that spirit can be evoked without detriment to the in- terests of the country.

May one not apply much of this reasoning to India? When was India ruled by Indians? Cen- turies have passed since the Hindu sovereign- ties were swept away by Muhammadan invaders from the North. I need not repeat the well- known facts which show conclusively that there is no such thing as one Indian nation. It is only partially true that there are Indian na- tions. Geographical boundaries, as Sir Alfred Lyall says, have no correspondence at all with distinctive institutions or groupings of the people and have comparatively little political significance. The Parsees - one of the most intelligent races, now classed as Indians have no country on the Indian continent. So, too, the Muhammadans ; one of their number rules an immense tract of territory mostly populated by Hindus. A Hindu Rajah of Kashmir rules a State mostly peopled by Muhammadans Maratha chiefs govern States not peopled by Marathas.

Nor do the leaders of the Nationalist move- ment in India seem to have a very clear idea of what they themselves want. For example, My. Dadabhai Naoroji used to apeak of "the very bright side of British rule": he has also told us how necessary it is "for the important political object pf maintaining British rule, to reserve by law for European alone such places of power of control only as may be necessary for the purpose"; and he has talked of the absolute necessity of the maintenance of super- vision of British rule, and of the conviction of the natives that a real regeneration, civilisation and advancement of India materially, morally, and politically, depends upon the long continu- ance of the British rule. It was not at one time his view that the natives should attain to the highest positions of control and power ; in fact, he considered that the con- trolling power of Englishmen in India was wanted as much for the benefit of India as for the benefit of Englan; he admitted the ne- cessity of maintaining European civil and military services in India, his contention being that the cost should not be wholly exacted from India.

Such was the view of Mr. Dadabbai Naoroji only a few years ago, but now, as the professed leader of the "moderates," not of the "extre- mists," the alteration of the services from Europeans to Indian is the key-note of his programme.

The administration in all services, depet- ments and details (he says), should be in the hands of the people themselves of India. as in the United Kingdom and the Colonies all taxation and legislation, and the power of spending the taxes are in the hands of the people of those countries, so should also be the rights of the people of India.

But do these claims represent the real wishes and aspirations of the mass of the peo- ple? Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji and his friends may collect "a body of able men and good speakers to go into all nooks and corners of India and inform the people in their own lan- guages of their British rights and how to exercise and enjoy them"; but will these men be the true friends of the millions of toiling peasants and labourers, of petty artisans and traders? That is the very different thing from a generous sympathy for the legitimate aspiration of the educated youth of India to obtain a greater share than heretofore in the Government and administration of their country. That is just what must be, and is being granted. We know that a definite move has been made with a

views of giving competent and able Indians the same access to the higher posts in the admi- nistration that are given to Britons. We know that proposals have com to the Secretary of State from the Governor Gerneral in Council, "fraught with the greatest possibilities." But hurry or precipitancy; either on the side of the officials or of the agitators, can only have the inevitable effect of setting the clock back. These are the words, not of sun-dried bureacrats, but of Mr. Morley, one of the prominent Liberal statesmen of the age, who is fully alive to his responsibilities as Secretary of State for India. He sees, just as Lord Cromer sees in Egypt, that the idea of transplanting British institutions wholesale into India is a fantastic and ludicrous drea, ; even if it could be done, it would not be for the good of India.

Again, Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji tells us that as the Indians are British citizens they are entitled to all British citizens' rights, inclusing that of absolute self-government. Of course the flaw in this apparently logical system of government is the theory that all subjects of Imperial rule enjoy equal political rights in every part of the King's dominions.

Our British rights [he continues] are beyon all question. Every British Indian subject has franchise in England as a matter of course, and the right even to become a member of Parliament : a fortiori, therefore, India ought to have universal suffrage and parliamentary institutions. Why should not an Indian enjoy the smae rights and privileges in India which he would enjoy when in Enland? Why has India not been greeted in the Imperial Con- ference as the Colonial Premiers have been?

The answer to his contention is that India is not one of the colonies, "those great com- munities and nations which have sprung from this island, and which are the great glory and honour of the people of this island." India is not one of the daughter nations which have inherited all that England has conquered for herself in the way of freedom and self-govern- ment. And yet, in the face of these facts, it is urged that the various races which people the continent of India can be admitted by adoption into the vast family, and that Great Britain may become in India the foster mother of federated free and separate States, placed on a fraternal footing with the great self-governing colonies, each with its own local autonamy and independence uner the immediate suprem- acy of England.

That is the ideal of the leaders of the so- called "moderate" party in the Indian nationa- list movement, and formulated by its ablest exponent, Sir Henry Cotton. But the key note of the position is the withdrawal of the British Army, and the vesting of the whole administera- tion, civil and military, executive and judicial, in the various local populations. With the British Army replaced by provincial national armies, which are to be recruited from the common people, and officered by the native gentry of the provinces in which they are to serve, we are told that there would be both a safeguard against internal disorder and a protection against attack from without.

But, Sir Henry Cotton argues, there is to be no room for democracy or republican insti- tutions. Though the United States of India are to be on the fraternal footing with the Colo- nies of England, they should be bound toge- ther by means of some political organisation other than the colonial supremacy of England." "The country still needs the hierarchical leadership of caste." "What is required, in the absence of an emasculating foreign army, is an organisation of small States, each with a prince at its head, and a small body of patrician aristocracy interposing between him and the lower orders of working-men." The existing Native States apparently, it is intended, should remain as they are, becoming federated with the "small States" mentioned above, which are to comprise the rest of India. But what is to prevent these princes from prey- ing on each other, and what is to become of the numerous solemn guarantees by which the British Government is bound towards the chiefs? Sir Henry himself admits "practical difficulties," such as "the general character of the relations between Hindus and Muham- madans, the jealousy which exists and manifests itself so frequently, even under British rule, in local bursts of popular fana- ticism."

Then there is the case of the European and Eurasian communities who may choose to reside in the country. Their welfare is to be secure by the formation of separate little settlements, with separate political constitu- tions, at suitable localities, at which their isolation would constrain them to adopt a more conciliatory demeanour towards the people of the country. I cannot help thinking that, to lay here some of the details of Sir Henry's "ideal," siffices to show that his views are on a par with the reckless policy of Mistapha Kamel Pasha in Egypt.
If space is permitted there are other subjects in Lord Cromer's report, in regard to which interesting comparisons might be drawn

between Egypt and India. One of the most important is the vernacular Press, to which the enlettered licence now allowed is con- sidered by the most respectable elements of native Egyptian society to be an unmixed evil. Lord Cromer admits that the agita- tors (who use the vernacular Press) are wholly unacrupulous as to the methods whoch they are prepared to adopt for imposing on the credulity of the masses and for inflaming their passions, and that "facts are generally mis- stated, and often wilfully perverted;" yet in the best course to follow was, not check the free- dom of the press, but for the mainenance of public order and to inspire confidence, to increase the British garrison at the cost of an additional charge of 45,000 a year on the Egyptian taxpayers.

In Lord Cromer's concluding words addressed to the British officials serving in Egypt, there is much that is applicable to India. British officials may find that certain sections of their own countrymen are disposed to misapprehend their motives, to misinterpret their acts, to uner- rate the very great difficulties of their posi- tions, to hold them responsible for abuses which they are powerless to repress, to mini- mise the good they have done, whilst laying exaggerated stress on all that still remains undone, and gernally to animadvert on the administration in a spirit, not of fair criticism, but of excessive acerbity.

But there is no ground for discouragement. And as to any widening of the breach between Indians and Europeans, it is capable of repair, not so much by change of policy or by the adoption of any striking measures of reform, as by the action of individuals and the proper understanding of the term--sympathy. ("Emprie Review").
